newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: FOCUS - NZ markets rally despite murky poll result.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - NZ markets rally despite murky poll result.

text.p: New Zealand markets rallied on Monday immediately after Saturday's inconclusive election.
The strongest to react was the New Zealand dollar which jumped nearly half a U.S. cent to US$0.6981/91 and the currency's Trade-Weighted Index rose to 66.61 from 66.05 on Friday.
The share market rallied 18.72 points, 0.8 percent, to 2,268.27 after two hours and was just shy of a 2-1/2 year high.
Long bond yields fell 10 basis points to 7.94 percent while 90-day bank bills fell six points to 9.86 percent.
Dealers said the key positive out of the election, which was largely in line with poll predictions, was the poor performance of the left-wing Alliance Party.

The election result gave 53 seats to the conservative National Party and its two allies, United and Act, against 50 for the two left-wing parties, Labour and the Alliance, leaving the nationalist NZ First with 17 seats to determine who becomes the government.

"There shouldn't be any shocks. There were no surprises about this result. If people hadn't put this result into their calculations then I don't know what they were doing," said Bankers Trust foreign exchange dealer Philip Lindberg.
National Bank chief dealer Stu Nattrass said the market had taken heart from the poor showing of the left-wing Alliance, which only won 11 percent of the vote for 13 seats.
"The positive thing was that the Alliance, which was the only party which could really cause damage, were taken out of play."
Nattrass said he was surprised at the strength of dollar and doubted it would be sustained, particularly if New Zealand First opted to go with Labour, as was most likely.
Lindberg said the foreign exchange market was prepared to live with uncertainty for up to six weeks.
Westpac Head of Financial Markets Chris Rand said the market had acted with relief and was anticipating a return of the offshore interest via eurokiwi and samurai issuance.
He agreed the market's main election fear had been the Alliance party -- that it would have been in a position to extract large concessions from the more moderate Labour Party.
"They really don't have that same sort of leverage and that certainly makes the market feel more comfortable," Rand said.
"The basic economic policy of NZ First isn't too far removed from either Labour or National," Rand said.
County NatWest sharebroker Neville Todd said the equities market had also feared the potential power of the Alliance.
"They are the ones who would likely inflict the most damage to a market-led economy and their influence is obviously going to be much less than we perhaps would have thought," Todd said.
International credit rating agency Standard & Poor's soothed markets by saying it was comfortable with the election result.

"It is broadly consistent with what we have been saying, which is we did not think if there was going to be a change of government that it would necessarily portend a substantial deviation from existing policy settings," Sovereign Risk Managing Director David Beers told Reuters.

"Based on the numbers, it seemed to us that if you tally up all the distribution, there is a majority in the new parliament advocating something like the stance of economic policies by both Labour and National governments for over a decade now."
Beers said he believed the majority of the voters had expressed their economic policy preferences pretty clearly.
"Those are ones that seem to us to be broadly consistent with the ratings we've got on New Zealand right now."
S&P rates New Zealand's sovereign risk at AA plus.
"Broadly speaking, we are comfortable with the types of scenarios that we can perceive going forward," Beers said.
-- Wellington newsroom 64 4 4734 746
